newsitem.title: NICARAGUA: Nicaragua's Aleman meets ex-Sandinista army chief.
newsitem.headline: Nicaragua's Aleman meets ex-Sandinista army chief.

text.p: New President Arnoldo Aleman on Tuesday met the former head of the Sandinista army as part of a bridge-building effort between Nicaragua's squabbling political extremes.

"We have different ideologies, but we are sons of the same country, and now we have entered a dialogue to search for the common good and fight against poverty," Aleman told reporters after meeting with former Sandinista People's Army chief Humberto Ortega.

Despite the end of its civil war seven years ago, Nicaragua remains bitterly polarised between the left-wing Sandinista Front and Aleman's right-wing Liberal Alliance coalition, which took power on Jan. 10.
Those hostilities had led former Sandinista President Daniel Ortega, Humberto's brother, to warn of political instability if the triumphant Liberals moved against the still-powerful Sandinistas.
Humberto Ortega, who led the Sandinsta army for more than 16 years, said he and Aleman met to discuss how to "strengthen the climate of tranquility and harmony in Nicaragua."
"It's important that the president is starting to talk with the Sandinista Front. This fact makes us happy," he said.
Late on Monday, Aleman met with Daniel Ortega and other top Sandinista ruling council members in a long-awaited meeting both men described as "positive and productive."
No agreements came out of the historic meeting, but the two parties agreed to continue negotiations designed to guarantee Nicaragua's political stability.

The meetings have eased tensions in Nicaragua, defusing a budding crisis that had darkened Aleman's first days in office, as Sandinistas warned of street protests against what they saw as a looming Liberal dictatorship.
Sandinista leaders accused the Liberals of trying to dominate the government, parliament and judicial system, leaving no independent state institutions.
Daniel Ortega, who ruled Nicaragua from 1979-1990, still had not recognised the legitimacy of Aleman's Oct. 20 election win, saying it was fraudulent.
Humberto Ortega retired to private life in 1995. Although virtually all of the army's high command is still of Sandinista origin, it has withdrawn from politics since Humberto stepped down.
